title: Allergies
content:
* Aim for good ventilation throughout your house to avoid moist air build-up.
  * Try to sleep with windows open to reduce the amount of moisture in the bedroom from breathing.


####    
Pollen
  * Keep the garden free of highly allergenic plants.
  * Try to stay indoors at times when the pollen count is at its highest, eg, the early evening.
  * Get someone else to mow your lawn.
  * Close your bedroom windows at night to prevent pollen entering.
  * Wear wrap-around sunglasses to avoid pollen getting into your eyes.
  * Have a shower and wash your hair at night to wash away pollen you may have ‘collected’ during the day.
  * Dry your clothes inside or in a tumble drier to avoid getting pollen on them.


####    
Animal dander
  * Keep pets outside, if possible.


####    
Skin allergies
  * Avoid strong soaps, perfumes and household cleansing products that may irritate sensitive skin.
  * Make sure jewellery and watches don't contain nickel, and are suitable for sensitive skin.


####    
Insect bites and stings
  * Make sure you wear footwear outdoors.
  * Cover your arms and legs.
  * Don't make sudden moves when bees or wasps are around.
  * Avoid strong perfume as it can attract insects.
  * Wear gloves when gardening.
  * Use insect repellent.


####    
Food allergies
If you have food allergies, know what they are and avoid those foods. A consultation with a dietitian can help you work out how to do this and still have a healthy, balanced diet. Ask your healthcare provider for a referral to a dietitian. Read more about [food allergies](https://healthify.nz/health-a-z/f/food-allergies).
####  How can I care for myself with allergies? 
#### Avoid allergies
It's not always practical to avoid the allergens you are allergic to. However, some things you can do include:
  * being careful about what you eat if you have food allergies
  * avoiding exposure to pets if you have animal allergies
  * keeping your home warm and dry if you have mould allergies
  * staying indoors and avoiding grassy areas if you have hay fever.


####    
Carry adrenaline
If you're at risk of life-threatening allergic reactions, carry adrenaline with you at all times. You also need to be trained in the correct use of an adrenaline auto-injector, EpiPen. Partners of adults should also be familiar with these devices.  
  
For children with allergies, parents or caregivers (including at daycare and schools) should also be familiar with how to use the EpiPen. 
####    
Allergic reaction action plan
Allergic reactions can cause a variety of symptoms ranging from mild to moderate reactions, through to severe and life-threatening reactions ([anaphylaxis](https://healthify.nz/health-a-z/a/anaphylaxis "Anaphylaxis")). You and your whānau need to be able to recognise the signs of an allergic reaction and anaphylaxis, and know what to do in an emergency.   
  
An allergic reaction action plan is a written document that outlines what to do if you have an allergic reaction. 
  * Here are [plans from the Australasian Society of Clinical Immunology and Allergy (ASCIA).(external link)](https://www.allergy.org.au/hp/ascia-plans-action-and-treatment "Open external link")


Carry your allergy action plan at all times or put your action plan somewhere you can easily find it in your home. If you don’t have an action plan, ask your healthcare provider to fill out one with you.
####    
Wear a medical bracelet
Wear a medical bracelet stating what you are allergic to. This can be very helpful for health professionals when treating you.
####    
Remind your healthcare team
Always remind your healthcare provider or pharmacist about your allergies before starting any new treatment, including complementary, over-the-counter and herbal medicines.
####  What support is available with allergies? 
[Allergy New Zealand(external link)](http://www.allergy.org.nz/ "Open external link") provides information, education and support for people with allergy, parents of children with allergy, teachers and health professionals.
